Finally one is united in the space of absolute truth. Existence means the coming of all things into existence. The Shen are so called because they subdue those things. Their theory concerns spirit, thought and mind, these three, and they regard the uniting of these as (the means of) leading (beings) to salvation. In their meditation self and other are one and not two, And they meditate with profound concentration in great equanimity. As for their practice, with regard to all beings they must act in the ways of kindness and love. As fruit (of their practice) they strive towards the Vehicle of the Primeval Shen. As presiding divinity, they meditate upon 'Dur-gsas rma-bo. Srid-gsen gTsug-phud, keep this in mind. This is the Bon of Death Rites and has the characteristics of relative truth. As for death ritual (in terms of) absolute truth, the Best of Shen who is expert in meditation and who has aroused feelings of immeasurable compassion towards feeble living beings, and who possesses the four measureless virtues, puts the good of others before himself and grasps body and mind (as one) in the things that characterize (the deceased). He must draw the design in blue on pure white paper. He must make (the image) complete with sense-organs and with (characteristic) smell (viz. used garments). He must put there the seed-syllables which will remove (risk of rebirth in) the places of evil rebirth. He must expel obstructing demons and get rid of the minions of hell. He must unite spirit, thought and mind, these three into one. He must make offerings to the Blessed Ones, and present gifts to the demons who inhabit the six regions.

'byung pa yi dwags glud kyis bskang // ngan song gnas sbyang rim par drang // dri ma mtshan byang rdzas la bstim // bar sa de la g.yang sar [30a] dbyung // 'jigs pa'i 'phrang bsgral bde bar dgod // sngon gyi bag chags rjes dran bshad // lha dang slob dpon bdag zhal sprad // dus drug 'tsho ba spyan gzigs bteg // 'dod yon zad med gter dang sprad // 'jig rten 'khor ba'i las spyod la // mi chags mi len mi zhen par // zhen pa bzlog pa'i bon sgo bshad // khams gsum sa dgu'i nyes dmigs bstan // yang dag thar lam bcu gnyis dang // g.yung drung theg pa'i sa bcu dang // mthar phyin sa gsum brod kha bting // bde ba'i gnas spar dbyings su dgod // phyir mi ldog dang phyir mi 'ong // lan gcig phyir 'ong rgyun du zhugs // dgra bcom 'bras thob smon lam gdab // lta dgongs nam mkha' lta bu yi // gshen rab rig pa'i rtsal ldan gyi // sems can don nus ma gtogs pa // phal dang phal gyi spyod yul min // gnyis phung ngan song brgyud nyen che // sngon nas sbyang pa'i 'phro can gyis // tshad med bzhi yi rgyun zhugs nas // sems can 'gro la sman par 'byung // rang bas gzhan don gtsor byed cing // 'gro la phan sems rtse gcig tu // byams dang snying rje'i gzhi ldan na // srid gshen theg pa 'gro ba'i don // don la mi gol 'jug sgo'i lam // mthar yang don dang 'bras bu ni // khams gsum sa dgu yar brgal nas // mos par spyod pa'i sa la gnas // mos spyod sa [30b] bzhi yar brgal nas // g.yung drung sa bcu rim bgrod cing // thar par mngon par 'tshang rgya'o // ces gsungs so /

He must satisfy with items of ransom the sprites and tormented spirits. He must lead (the deceased), removing one by one (the risks of rebirth in) the unhappy regions. He must then dissolve (the deceased) into the clothes and characterizing items, and bring him out from the Intermediate State into Blessedness. He must take him through the path of fear and establish him in happiness. He must speak to him, reminding him of former adverse influences. Bring him face to face with his tutelary divinity and his lama. Set up a display of sustenance for the six (daily) periods. Let him see treasure of limitless desirable things, and explain the bon door which disposes of desire, so that one does not yearn for, does not seize at, does not desire the activities of worldly existence. Show the disadvantages of the nine stages of the threefold world, and display the joys of the twelve ways of salvation, of the ten stages of the Swastika Way and of the three final stages. Establish him in the sphere where he is raised up to the place of bliss. Pray that he may gain the fruits of a non-returner, of a once-returner, of one who enters the stream, of an arhat. Except for the Best of Shen, expert in knowledge and whose meditation is (vast) like the heavens, this ability in the affairs of living beings is no sphere of activity for ordinary people. Both (the officiator and the deceased) will fail, and there is great danger of connecting up with evil rebirths. One who has been continuously purified from previous times and who has entered the stream of the four measureless virtues, is able to benefit living beings. Making other’s concern more important than his own, if his mind is one-pointedly directed towards benefitting beings, and is established in kindness and compassion, there will be benefit in following the Way of the Shen of Existence. There will be no error in the intention. This is the entrance-way. Then finally as the result and the effect, one will traverse the nine stages of the threefold world, and rest in the Stage of Devotional Practice. Then having traversed the four stages of Devotional Practice, one will traverse the ten Swastika Stages and become a perfect buddha in the state of salvation. This is what he said.
V. DGE BSNYEN THEG PA
V. THE WAY OF THE VIRTUOUS ADHERERS
[vol. ga, f. 164a6 onwards]
(Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud said:)

thams cad mkhyen pa'i ston pa lags // ston pas theg pa'i rim pa las // rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis su gsungs // rgyu yi theg pa'i rim pa sogs // bskos pa'i gshen la gnyer du gtad // da lta 'bras bu'i theg pa la // theg [164b] pa lnga pa dge bsnyen bon // bdag la gnyer du gtad gsungs pa // dge zhes bya ba ci ltar dge // bsnyen na ci ltar bsnyen pa lags // rtsa ba'i 'byung khungs gang la gtogs // bdag cag 'khor la bstan du gsol //

All-knowing teacher! You have told us that the series of vehicles are divided into those of cause and effect. The series of the vehicles of cause have been committed to the Shen responsible. Now as for the vehicles of effect, you have said that you will commit to my keeping the fifth vehicle, that of the Virtuous Adherers. What does ‘Virtuous’ mean in this context? and what does ‘Adherer’ mean? Where does the basic origin belong? I beg you to inform me and my entourage.
de la ston pas bka' stsal pa / nyon cig tshangs pa gtsug phud nyon //
Then the Teacher said: Listen, Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud, listen!

dge bsnyen theg pa'i bon sgo ni // dge zhes bya ba sdig pa med // lus ngag yid gsum dge bar bkol // dang du blang bas dge ba zhes // bsnyen zhes bya ba yang dag don // phyin ci ma log bsnyen pas bsnyen // dge la bsnyen cing tshul la gnas // yang dag don la 'jug spyod do // rtsa ba'i 'byung khungs mdo las byung //

As for the way of bon, the vehicle of Virtuous Adherers, ‘Virtuous’ means free from evil, committed to virtue in Body, Speech and Mind, and because one must comply with this, we use the term ‘virtue’. ‘Adherer’ implies adhering infallibly to this perfect matter, and so we use the term ‘adherer’. Adhering to virtue and keeping to the pattern, one enters upon this perfect matter. The basic origin comes from the sutras.
bon la rgya che grangs mang yang // tshur bsdus rnam pa bzhi ru 'dus // mdo 'bum gzungs gsum man ngag bzhi //
Although bon is vast and beyond number, Compressing it, we bring it together in four kinds, (i) sūtras, (ii) the ‘Perfection of Wisdom’, (iii) spells, and (iv) wise lore.

man ngag dpon gsas lung gi bon // gzungs ni chab dkar nag po sngags // 'bum ni rgyas pa spyir spro ba // mdo ni rgyu 'bras gzhal bya ste // theg pa thams cad rtsa ba ni // mdo sde dag las byung ba'o //

Wise lore is the inspired bon of the Master-Sages. Spells are the mantras of the White Waters and the Black. The ‘Perfection of Wisdom’ is the composition of ten thousand verses which spreads everywhere in its full form. The sutras are cause and effect and the appraisal. The basis of all vehicles has come from the sūtras.
rgyu 'bras gzhal zhes bya ba ni // sngon du btang ba rgyu ru ste // phyis su 'byung ba 'bras bu'o // gzhal bya dag ni dka' sla gnyis //
As for the cause, the effect and the appraisal, that which is put first is the cause and that which appears afterwards is the effect, while the appraisal comprises easy and difficult couples.

de yang thog mar rgyu 'bras la // zhing pa dag dang so nam 'dra // sa bon sngon du btab pa na // 'bras bu ljang pa rjes su 'byung // ljang pa dag la brten pa yi // lo 'bras me tog bcud du smin // 'gro ba sems can gsos su 'gyur //

Now first as for cause and effect, it is like the farmer and work on the fields. First the seed is planted and the shoots appear afterwards as the fruit (or effect). Following upon the shoots the leaves, flowers and grains ripen into the sustenance, which sustains living beings.

dpe don de yi mtshon nas su // dad pa sngon du btang ba na // brtson 'grus rjes su 'byung bar 'gyur // dad pa bskyed [165a] na brtson 'grus myur // le lo med pa phyir mi ldog // btson 'grus sngon du btang ba na // shes rab rnam gsum 'bras bu 'byung // thos dang bsam dang sgom pa yis // gzung so gdag sgo go lam phyed // shes rab sngon du song ba na // 'bras bu dge bcu rjes su 'byung // dge bcu spyad na thar pa thob // mi dge spyad na ngan song brgyud // dge bcu sngon du btang ba na // 'bras bu pha rol phyin bcu thob // sbyin pa brtson 'grus dka' thub zhi // bzod dang bsam gtan spyod yul dag // stobs dang snying rje smon lam mchog // thabs dang shes rab rgyud 'byang ngo //

As is shown by this metaphor, if faith is put first, zeal will come afterwards. If faith is produced, zeal comes quickly, and there is no reverting to laziness. Then if zeal is put first, the three aspects of wisdom will come as effect, and by learning, reflecting and meditating, the field of study, the terminology and the course of understanding are characterized. If wisdom goes first, the ten virtues come afterwards as the effect. If one practises the ten virtues, one achieves release. If one practises evil, one continues in a series of evil rebirths. If one puts the ten virtues first, one gains as effect the ten perfections, generosity, zeal, gentleness in adversity, forbearance, mental repose (which gives) purity in one’s sphere of action, strength, compassion, excellent prayer, method and wisdom. These purify the spirit.

pha rol phyin pa bcu spyad na // g.yung drung sa bcu rim gyis non // sa lam rim bgrod 'khrul pa med // g.yung drung theg pa'i sar 'dzegs nas // sangs rgyas sa la 'khod par 'gyur // sangs rgyas sa la gnas la kyang // 'gro ba sems. can dpal du ste // rgyu dang 'bras bu'i mtshan nyid do //

If one practises the ten perfections, one treads in due order the ten Swastika stages, and there is no delusion traversing this order of stages. Having ascended the stage of the Swastika Vehicle, One is established in the stage of buddhahood. Abiding in the stage of buddhahood, One becomes the glory of living beings. Such are the indications of cause and effect.

gzhal bya dka' dang sla ba ste // yig rtsis rgyud la 'jug dka' yang // mthun pa'i grogs kyis brid pa sla // sems bskyed ma bzhi skye dka' yang // rang la dpe blang snying rje sla // sbyin pa phyogs med gtong dka' yang // rkyen gyis bslang na grol ba sla //

As for the appraisal of easy and difficult things, although it is difficult to fix writing and calculation in the mind, it is easy to impose it with suitable help, Although it is difficult to produce the four kinds of Thought-raising towards Enlightenment, compassion is easy if one uses oneself as example. Although it is difficult to give gifts indiscriminately, it is easy to part with them if one arouses the desire as occasion arises.

tshul khrims 'chal med bsrung dka' yang // khrims kyis bcad na thub pa sla // bzod pa sran bcas bsgom dka' yang // sgyu ma bslab na thob pa sla // brtson 'grus drag po bskyed dka' yang // bde sdug gzhal na brtson pa sla // bsam gtan mnyam par gnas dka' yang // ngang thag bsring na brtan pa sla // dge ba'i stobs la gzhug dka' yang // sems rgya bskyed na 'grub pa sla // [165b] snying rje dpag med bskyed dka' yang // rang rgyud gzhal na skye ba sla // smon lam re dogs med dka' yang // phyogs med bsten na mthar phyin sla // thabs mchog rmongs pa med dka' yang // bkri drang bgyid na 'dul ba sla // shes rab 'khrul pa med dka' yang // rnam gsum rgyud sbyang mthar phyin sla // gzhal bya dka' sla'i mtshan nyid do //

Although it is difficult to keep rules of morality intact, it is easy to do so, if discipline is exercised. Although it is difficult to practise patient forbearance, it is easy to do so, if one has learned about illusion, Although it is difficult to arouse strong zeal, effort is easy, if one makes an appraisal of happiness and suffering. Although it is difficult to remain in a state of repose, it is easy to be constant, if one perseveres. Although it is difficult to embark upon virtuous power, it is easy to effect it, if one widens one’s mind. Although it is difficult to arouse immeasurable compassion, it is easy to arouse it, if one appraises one’s own soul-series. Although prayer is difficult free from hopes and fears, it is easy to perfect it, if one keeps impartial. Although perfect method free from folly is difficult, it is easy to convert, if one guides and leads. Although wisdom free from delusion is difficult, it is easy to perfect it, if one purifies the three aspects of it in one’s own soul-series. Such are the indications of what is difficult and easy in the matter of appraisals.
[f. 166a5, onwards]

de la yang tshangs pa gtsug phud kyis gsol pa / rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa yi // cir yang sprul pa'i sku mchog lags // mdo sde dag las byung ba yi // theg pa lnga pa dge bsnyen bon // ma nor don la 'jug pa nas // mi 'khyar don la bsgrub pa na // rgyu 'bras rtsa ba ci ltar bsrung // spyod tshul rim pa ci ltar lags //

Then again Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud asked: O All-knowing One, whose excellent form may be made manifest in any way soever! As for this fifth vehicle, the bon of Virtuous Adherers, which originates from the sūtras, if one is to embark upon it free of error and practise this matter unerringly, how is the basis of cause and effect to be maintained, and what is the sequence of the practice?

[166b] de la ston pas bka' stsal pa / nyon cig tshangs pa gtsug phud 'khor // rgyu 'bras rtsa ba 'di lta ste // 'khor ba'i las la blo ldog cing // thar pa'i don la spro bskyed nas // rtse gcig byang chub bsgrub pa na // sdig bcu mi dge rgyab tu bor // dge bcu rnam dag dang du blang //

To this the Teacher replied: Listen, Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud together with your entourage. The basis of cause and effect is like this. Turning your mind from the affairs of the world and arousing feelings of joy in this matter of salvation, when you aim one-pointedly at enlightenment, you must abandon completely the ten evil actions and comply with the ten virtuous actions.
de yang gong du bstan pa ltar // sdig pa mi dge bcu po ni // lus kyi gsum dang ngag gi gsum // yid kyi bzhi las sogs pa'o //
As has been taught before, there are ten evil actions, three of body, three of speech, four of mind and so on.

rtsa ba de las byung ba yi // mtshams med lnga dang nye ba lnga // lji ba bzhi dang log pa brgyad // 'khrul pa dgu dang mi dge bcu // 'khrul rtog bcu ste 'khor ba'i las // bgyid dang bgyi ru rtsal ba dang // rjes su yi rang spang bar bgyi // 'khor bar ltung ba'i rgyu yin pas // rtsa ba'i dug lnga'i las spyod ni // shin tu dam par srung ba gces // dge ba rnam dag bcu bo ni // de las so so'i gnyen po ste // lus kyi gsum dang ngag gi gsum // yid kyi bzhi las sogs pa dang //

From this basis arise the five immeasurable sins and the five related to them, the four grave offences and the eight reversals, the nine delusions and the ten evils, the ten misapprehensions. You must abandon doing these things, trying to get them done and taking pleasure in them. They are the cause of sin in the world, so it is very important to avoid the practice of these five basic evils. As for the ten pure virtues, they are the antidotes of each type of action, three of the body, three of speech, four of the mind and so on.

rtsa ba de las gyes pa yi // byams chen lnga dang ltos pa lnga // gus pa bzhi dang 'dun pa brgyad // nges pa dgu dang dge ba bcu // gzhol ba bcu ste thar pa'i las // bgyid dang bgyi ru rtsal ba dang // rjes su yi rang blang bar bya // thar par bgrod pa'i rgyu yin pas // rtsa ba'i ye shes lnga po ni // shin tu nges par blang ba gces // tshangs pa gtsug phud sprul pa'i gshen // rgyu 'bras spang blang rtsa ba'o //

Derived from the basic ones are the five great acts of love and the five related to them, the four acts of respect and the eight aspirations, the nine certainties and the ten virtues, the ten diligent applications, You must apply yourself to doing them, trying to get them done and taking pleasure in them. They are the cause of advance towards salvation, so it is very important to practise decidedly these five basic wisdoms. Tshans-pa gTsug-phud, O Shen who is manifest at will! Even such are the basic matters to be avoided and to be practised, and such are their causes and effects.

spyod tshul rim pa 'di lta tes // dge bsnyen gtan spyod rnam pa lnga // dag pa khrus kyi spyod pa dang // phyag skor mos 'dun spyod pa dang // sku gdung tsha tsha'i [167a] spyod pa dang // rnam dag mchod gtor spyod pa dang // tshogs rdzogs go cha'i spyod pa'o //

Now the sequence of practice is like this: there are five kinds of fixed practice for Virtuous Adherers, the practice of pure ablutions, the practice of salutations, circumambulations and devotions, the practice of shrines and tsha-tsha, the practice of the pure offering of water in worship, the practice of the armour of the perfected accumulations (of knowledge and merit).
dge bsnyen gtan khrims sna lnga las // dge bsnyen spyod tshul rnam pa lnga // phyi tshul nang khrims zung 'brel na // sgrib sbyang tshogs gnyis rdzogs par 'gyur // zhes bka' stsal to /

From the five kinds of fixed rules of Virtuous Adherers come the five kinds of practice of Virtuous Adherers When the outer form and the inner law are united defilements are removed and the two accumulations are perfected. So he spoke.

de la tshangs pa gtsug phud kyis gsol pa / rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa yi // 'gro ba'i mgon gyur gshen rab lags // dge bsnyen theg pa'i bon sgo las // phyi yi tshul dang nang gi khrims // nang khrims gong du gsungs lags kyang // phyi yi spyod tshul rim pa la // lag len go rim ci ltar lags // bdag cag rig pa'i blo rtsal zhan // thams cad mkhyen pas bshad du gsol // zhes gsol to /

At that Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud replied: O All-Knowing Guardian of living beings, Best of Shen! As for the bon way of the Vehicle of Virtuous Adherers, its outer form and its inner law, although you have explained the inner law above, what is the order of techniques in the outward form of practice? Our intellectual understanding is weak. We beg you, All-Knowing One, to tell us. Thus they asked him,

de la ston pas bka' stsal pa / tshangs pa gtsug phud la sogs 'dus pa'i 'khor / dus 'dir tshogs pa rnams kyang / sgrib gnyis byang zhing tshogs gnyis rdzogs pa dang / phyi rabs rnams la dper bstan pa'i phyir du / rgyu dge ba'i rtsa ba las / bsod nams kyi tshogs rdzogs shing sgrib pa sbyang dgos pa yin pas / phyag skor mos gus dang mchod pa'i rten la / gshen gyi pho brang zhig bzhengs su 'tshal gyis / rma lo dang g.yu lo dang / tshangs pa gtsug phud dang / spang la nam gshen dang / gto rgyal khri shes dang / g.yu drung sems dpa' khyed rnams kyis / yo byad dang rdzas cha mang po sog cig /rje rigs kyi rgyal po 'khor lo 'od gsal 'khor dang bcas pas / tshogs sbyor rgyu'i yon bdag gyis [167b] shig / ces gsungs nas /

and the Teacher replied: Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud and the rest of the assembled company who are gathered here at this time! In order to instruct future generations, since in accordance with the basic virtues which are the cause (of all advance), we must perfect the accumulating of merit and remove our defilements, we should found a Shen Palace as a basis for our salutations, circumambulations, devotions and worship. Therefore O rMa-lo, gYu-lo, Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud, sPang-la nam-gshen, gTo-rgyal khri-shes, all you Swastika Beings, gather together implements and materials. And you, O King 'Khor-lo 'od-gsal of royal lineage, together with your entourage, be benefactor of the required materials.

'khor rnams la bka' stsal pa / rje rigs kyi rgyal po 'khor lo 'od gsal dang / rgyal po'i khab dga' ba can gyi mi rnams dang / g.yung drung sems dpa' rnams kyis / phun sum tshogs pa'i yo byad mang po bsags te / bzo rgyal gar ma li sho la bka' stsal nas / bzhengs su gsol te / de yang lcags ri pho 'dom bzhi rgya'i nang du / rming gzhi khri 'phangs rim lnga brtsigs pa / de'i steng du logs bzhi rdzu 'phrul dra ba la / g.yung drung gi pa tras gtam pa / phyi log la pho 'dom brgya nyi shus 'khor ba / de'i nang du gser gyi ka ba dang / g.yu'i gdung ma dang / nyi zla'i ka zhu dang / pad ma'i ka gdan dang / gzha' tshon gyi dpyam gdung dang / 'khor lo'i dpyam bar dang / nor bu'i dpyam gdung dang / gzha' sprin gyi pa tra dang nam kha'i ya gad dang / rgyu skar gyi za ra tshags dang / gzha' tshon gyi dar bu khad rlob pa /

Having thus addressed the company, King 'Khor-lo 'od-gsal of royal lineage, the people of the royal city dGa'-ba-can, together with the Swastika Beings, gathered together many necessary things of excellent quality, and they asked the Royal Artisan Gar-ma-li-sho to build. Then inside a surrounding wall 400 fathoms in circumference, he built foundations in five ascending steps, and on these he built four walls of a criss-cross pattern and decorated with swastika designs. The outer walls were 120 fathoms in circumference. Inside there were golden pillars and blue crossbeams. On the pillar capitals were designs of the sun and moon and the bases were designed as lotuses. The laths were coloured like the rainbow. There were wheel-patterns between the laths and jewel-patterns on the ends of the (protruding) laths. There were rainbow and cloud designs and sky-coloured decorative eaves, and it was hung with looped patterns of the lunar mansions and pleated hangings of rainbow colours.

de'i steng du rta dbab rim pa lnga ni / dkar ljang dmar sngo gser mdog dang lnga la / 'byung lnga'i pa tras spras pa / de'i steng du bum pa shel gur dkar po la / rin po che'i 'gur chu dang / za ra tshags gis brgyan pa / de'i steng bre srog 'khor lo char khebs ldan pa / de la tog dang bya ru dar chun gyi brgyan pa /

Above there was a platform rising in five steps, white, green, red, blue and yellow, and decorated with the symbols of the five elements. On top of this (he built) the great vase, white as crystal, decorated with garlands of gems and decorative devices. Above this was a square support, and then the ‘core of life’, the rings and the umbrella. Above this was the top-piece with the (two) horns hung with garlands.
sgo bzhi phyogs bzhi'i kha dog la / gzha' tshon gyi sgo khyud dang / gser gyi sgo 'gram dang / bye ru'i sgo skyes btsug pa /
As for the colours of the four sides, the walls around the doors were of rainbow colours, the edge of the doorway was gold and the doors themselves he made coral red.

de lta bu'i gzhal yas khang nyams dga' ba yid du 'ong ba / blta na sdug pa / spa zhing brjid pa / gzi zhing mtho ba / rab tu brtan pa / bar 'khyams 'dod yon gyi ra ba dang [168a] bcas pa / phyi sgo la rgyal chen bzhi'i pho brang bcas pa / de lta bu'i gshen gyi pho brang chen po ni / lha dang klu dang mi la sogs pa / dge ba la 'dun pa rnams kyis bzhengs pas / gung zhag bco lnga'i dus la grub bo /

Such was the pleasing and delightful palace, beautiful to behold, gloriously adorned, splendid and lofty, well and truly firm, and provided with a surrounding veranda with the necessary offerings, which wash established by the gods, the serpents, by men and by all who delighted in virtue, and it was completed in fifteen days.

de la ston pas bde bar gshegs pa'i sku gdung rnam dag gi rgyud las / mu tra lha'i dkyil 'khor zhal phyes nas / mnga' dbul dang rab gnas rgya chen por mdzad de / mtshan yang g.yung drung bkod legs kyi mchod rten zhes bya ba gsol to / de la yang steng gi lha dang / 'og gi klu dang / bar gyi mi rnams kyang shin tu spro ba skyes nas thams cad kun gyis mngon par bstod do /

Then, in accordance with the ritual entitled ‘Pure Reliquary of the Blessed Ones’, the Teacher made manifest the mystic circle of the Mu-tra Gods, and performed a great ceremony of dedication and consecration, and he gave it the name of the ‘Well-Established Swastika Stupa’. Then the gods from above, the serpents from below, and human beings of the middle regions were all very joyful and all sang praises.
de la yang ston pas / dge bsnyen theg pa'i spyod tshul gtan la phab ste stsal pa /
Then again the Teacher set forth the manner of practice of the Vehicle of Virtuous Adherers, saying:

tshangs pa gtsug phud gang zhig rigs kyi bu dang rigs kyi bu mo dag / sdig pa mi dge ba'i las spangs nas / dge ba'i las dang du blang bar 'dod na / tshul dang khrims kyi las la zhugs nas / yang dag mthar phyin pa'i don dang ldan pa'i skyes bu / 'gro ba 'dul ba / kha lo bsgyur ba / rig pa gsal ba / stobs dang ldan pa / rmid du byung ba / don mi bsnyel ba'i gzungs thob pa / rnam par dag pa'i dge ba la 'dun zhing / mang po 'tshogs pa'i rgya mtsho gnon pa / gshen gyi mkhan slob dang dpang po / de lta bu'i mdun du 'khod nas / dge bsnyen gyi khrims nod par bya ste / phyi'i tshul gos lnga dang / nang gi gtan khrims lnga dang / bar gyi spyod lam lnga mthun par bya zhing / theg pa la [168b] 'jug ste / dang po phyi'i tshul gos lnga ni / stod gos dang / smad shams dang / chag non dang / rmad 'og dang / rmad gos phyar bu dang lnga'o /

O Tshangs-pa gTsug-phud and whichever sons of the lineage and daughters of the lineage are desirous of abandoning evil and applying themselves honestly to virtuous actions, they must enter this way and this law and (come) to the presence of a perfected sage, who converts living beings and guides them, whose intellect is clear, who is strong and wonderful, a sure (not forgetting the meaning) master of spells, who is zealous for the purest virtue, controlling a great company (of religious). They must come to the presence of such a Shen abbot, such a Shen teacher and such a Shen witness, and they must receive the law of Virtuous Adherers, and act in conformity with the outward manner (of the law) relating to the five articles of apparel, the five firm inner laws, and the five intermediate practices. When one enters this vehicle, first there is the outward manner relating to the five articles of apparel, the upper garment, the lower garment, the sandals, the ordinary cloak and the special cloak.

nang gi khrims lnga ni / zhe sdang gi dbang gis srog gcod pa dang / 'dod chags gi dbang gis ma byin pa len pa dang / gti mug gi dbang gis rgyu 'bras mi rtsi thob rdzobs su spyod pa dang / nga rgyal gyi dbang gis dreg pa'i las bgyid ba dang / 'phra dog gi dbang gis tshig rtsub mo dang / ngag 'khyal ba dang / rdzun dang 'phra ma smra ba dang lnga spang ba'o /

As for the five inner laws, one must avoid killing in anger, stealing through covetousness, acting ambitiously without taking account of causes and effects as through ignorance, acting brazenly through pride, and quarrelling, talking nonsense and telling lies and slanders, all as through envy.
blang ba ni de las bzlog ste / yon tan gyi tshogs dpag tu med pa'o /
One must apply oneself to the opposite of these, and then the accumulation of good qualities will be without measure.

bar gyi spyod tshul lnga ni / dag pa khrus bgyid pa dang / phyag skor mos 'dun spyod pa dang / sku gdung gi tsha tsha 'debs pa dang / rnam dag gi mchod gtor gtong ba dang / tshogs bsags pa'i yan lag las / mchod pa 'bul ba dang lnga'o /

As for the five intermediate practices, they are the performance of ablutions, the practice of salutations, circumambulations and devotions, the attendance on shrines and tsha-tsha, the practice of the pure offering of water in worship, and from the items that produce an accumulation of merit the one of ceremonial worship.
VI. DRANG SRONG THEG PA
VI. THE WAY OF THE GREAT ASCETICS
[vol. ga, f. 242b6 onwards]
yang ston pas bka' stsal pa / nyon cig rnam [243a] dag gtsug phud nyon // srung ba'i tshul la rnam pa gnyis // thabs la brten te srung tshul dang // rang bzhin spyod pa'i 'dra tshul lo //

Again the Teacher said: Listen, rNam-dag gTsug-phud, listen! The manner of keeping (to this vehicle) is twofold, keeping to it by adhering to methodical instructions, and by all manner of examples for one’s personal practice.

thabs la brten te srung tshul ni // rnam pa gnyis su 'byung ba ste // blang dang dbog pa gnyis su ste // blang ba dag la rnam pa gsum // mkhan dang slob dpon dpang po rnams // mkhan po gser gyi mchod rten 'dra // dpang po 'gyur med ri bo 'dra // slob dpon dri med shel sgong 'dra // de la ma nyams rnam pa gsum // gser gyi mchod rten mdangs ma nyams // 'gyur med ri bo dpangs ma nyams // dri med shel sgong 'od ma nyams // nyams pa med cing gol ba med // rnam gsum blo dang ldan pa yis // sgo gsum g.yeng ba'i tshogs spangs nas // lus ngag yid gsum gus pa yis // mkhan slob dpang po'i mdun drung du // dga' dang dad dang gus pas blang // dug gsum bag chags bdar thag gcad // sku gsum ye shes 'bras thob 'gyur // dpang po'i drung du khas blangs pa // khas blangs ma yin dam bca' yin // dam la 'gal na 'bras bu 'tshig // skye ba lnga brgyar ngan song brgyud // gar skyes slu ba rgyun tu 'ong //

As for keeping to it by adhering to methodical instructions, this appears in two aspects: as receiving and as bestowing. The process of receiving has three aspects, (connected with) the abbot, the teacher, and the witness. The abbot is likened to a golden shrine. The witness is likened to a firm mountain. The teacher is likened to an immaculate crystal ball. Their freedom from defect is of three kinds. There is no defect in the lustre of a golden shrine. There is no defect in the height of a firm mountain. There is no defect in the light of an immaculate crystal ball. They are free from defects and free from error. With one’s threefold mind (viz. trained in learning [thos], thought [bsam] and meditation [sgom]), avoiding the heaps of distractions of Body, Speech and Mind, with the devotion of all three, One should receive (initiation) with joy, faith and devotion in the presence of the abbot, the teacher and witness. One must cut off completely the pervasive influences of the Three Evils, and one will gain the fruit of knowledge of the Three Buddha Bodies. What you promise in the presence of the witness is not (just) a promise. It is a vow. If you break an oath, the (good) effects are destroyed. For 500 rebirths you will pass through the realms of wretchedness. Wherever you are born, there will always be ensnarements.
byams dang snying rje btang snyoms gsum // thabs dang tshul. dang spyod lam gsum // rnam par dag pa'i. sgo nas blang //
Love, compassion, equanimity, these three, method, manner, practice, these three, must be taken up with a completely pure disposition.

dbog pa dag la rnam pa gsum // rtsa ba yan lag nying lag gsum // srog gcod pa dang ma byin blang // mi gtsang spyod dang che dregs bdud // gnyis brgya lnga bcu rdzogs par dbog // de'i yan lag sde bzhi las // kha zas sde dang gon pa'i sde // khri stan sde dang grogs [243b] kyi sde //

The process of bestowing is of three kinds, the roots, the limbs, the branches. (The rules concerning) taking life and stealing, impure behaviour and the demon of arrogance, these are given in the full form of 250 items. As for the four sections which are their ‘limbs’, there is the section on food, on dress, on couches and on friends.

de la so sor dbye ba ni // thog mar kha zas sde bzhi las // mang thun sha dang yu ti chang // ag tsong dag dang rnam pa gsum // dus ma yin gyi kha zas bzhi // sha la rnam pa bzhi yin te // ltung dang nyes dang nyams pa dang // sbyang du btub dang rnam pa bzhi // spyir yang sha yi nyes pa ni // tshe rabs thog ma med pa nas // da lta'i lus blangs yan chad du // srid pa ci ltar srid pa na // srog dbugs bsdus pa'i sems can rnams // pha mar ma gyur gcig kyang med // de'i phyir skye 'gro'i sems can 'di // dkar dmar thig le'i rgyu las grub //

Taking them each separately, as for the section on food, (we discuss) meat and chang, onions as the third item, and meals at improper times as the fourth. (Eating of) meat may be considered in a fourfold way, as sinful, as harmful, as debilitating, and fourthly as (a sin) capable of being washed away. Now as for the harm of meat-eating in general, from the beginningless series of living states to the receiving of this present body, however they originated in their origins, of all living beings who draw breath, there is no one who has not been parent of any other. In this way these living beings are produced from the white and red drops which are their cause.

de ni srid pa'i snying po ste // sred dang len pa'i sa bon las // 'byung ba bzhi yi gzugs su grub // phyi snod 'byung ba rnam bzhi la // nang bcud gnas pa ci bzhin du // bzhi bsdud gzugs kyi phung po la // srin bu'i grong khyer sum brgya drug // phyi snod nang bcud bzhin du chags // srin bu'i khrong khyer re re la // 'phra mo'i sems can khri phrag re // de las de 'gyur rtsis las 'das // sems can re re'i srog bcad na // 'phra mo'i sems can grangs med gum // sems can re re bkol spyad na // 'pha mo'i sems can grangs med bsngal //

This is the essence of existence, and from this seed (characterized by) desiring and taking, they are produced as bodies formed of the four elements. Just as living beings who are the essence abide in the outer world of the four elements which is their vessel, likewise in the personal body formed of the four elements there are 360 communities of worms. Just as the internal essences are manifest in the outer vessel, so in each community of worms there are ten of thousands of minute beings, and the ones that are produced from them surpass all calculation. For every being that is killed numberless minute beings die. For every being that you set to work numberless minute beings suffer.

sems can re re'i mngal spyad na // 'phra mo'i sems can grangs med brgyal // de'i phyir 'di yi nyes pa ni // srog bcad srin bu'i sdug bsngal ni // nags tshal dag la me btang 'dra // khrag gi zegs ma me ru mthong // bkol spyad srin bu'i sdug bsngal ni // thar med brtson rar tshud pa 'dra // lus srog bsdam pa'i she mang ni // lcags kyi tha ram dam par mthong // mngal [244a] spyod srin bu'i sdug bsngal ni // rgyal khams nad yams phyo ba 'dra // lus zungs thig le dug tu mthong // de'i phyir srog spyod ma byin blang // mi gtsang spyod pa'i nyes pa yis // gtan du thar med ltung ba yang // bzhi bsdus phung po'i rgyu las 'byung // phung po'i bcud las sha ru byung //

For every being whose womb is worked countless small living beings feel faint. Therefore as for its harmfulness, this taking of life and the suffering of worms is like setting fire to a forest, for they see the drops of blood like fire. As for setting animals to work and the suffering of worms, they feel as though pressed into a dungeon where there is no escape. As for the wretchedness of having their life-force in harness, they see themselves as bound with iron fetters. As for copulation and the suffering of worms then, it is as though an epidemic pervaded their whole realm, and they see the bodily element of seed as though it were poison. Thus taking life and stealing and the evil of impure behaviour are certainly mortal sins, and they have as their cause the physical body formed of the four elements. The essence of the physical body emerges as flesh.

de'i phyir sha la spyod pa ni // srin po nying sha can dang 'dra // ro mchog tshor ba brod pa la // zhe ldang me ltar 'bar ba 'byung // srog bcad bzhin du srog la brod // gzhan kyang srog la rlom pa gdong // glo bur bar chod hur pa dang // nyu le 'jab bu de las byung // gsad gcad rtsa ba sha la thug // nus pa bcud du smin pa las // 'dod chags chu ltar khol ba 'byung // mi gtsang spyod bzhin mi gtsang 'dod // tshims pa med cing ngoms pa med // gang dag gzugs la rlom pa gtong // 'khrig cing sbyor. bas sred len 'phrod // 'khor ba'i skye 'phel de las 'byung //

So this addiction to flesh reminds one of demons who eat their own kind. From relishing the sense of its excellent taste anger arises burning like fire. Delighting in killing as he kills, a demon glories in taking the lives of others. Sudden impediments and trickery and mean thieving all come from it. The root cause of slaying is concerned with flesh. Fleshly potency develops into an essence and desire arises like boiling water. In the act of impurity one desires impurity. There is no contenting and no satisfying. Revelling transmits itself into all bodies there are. Desiring and grasping are passed on through copulation. From all this comes the birth-increase of this world.

skye rga na 'chi sha la thug // khu ba rtsa rgyud 'grim pa las // gti mug mun ltar 'thib pa 'byung // gnyid log bzhin du gnyid la brod // bying mug le lo che ba yis // tshe 'di gnyid log rmi lam 'dra // g.yeng skyon le lo de las byung //

Birth, old age, sickness and death are all concerned with flesh. The seminal essence pervades the channels of the body, and so there comes mental torpor like thickening darkness. In the act of sleeping, one delights in sleep. With such great drowsiness and indolence this life becomes like a sleeping dream. From all this come distraction and indolence.

mi lus chud zos sha la thug // dangs ma kha dog mdangs la song // lang tsho stobs shed rgyas pa las // nga rgyal rlung ltar 'tshub pa 'byung // nga rgyal bzhin du dregs pa skye // chen po dag la 'gran ya nga // gzhan dag yul la rlom pa gtong // bdag rgyal gzhan [244b] pham de las 'byung // 'thab rtsod rtsa ba de la thug //

The wasting of the human body is concerned with flesh. Vitality passes into colour and complexion. Strength of youth grows in force. From this comes pride which rages like a storm, and together with pride comes arrogance. So contending against one’s superiors, acting boisterously in others’ domains, triumph for oneself and discomforture for others, this is the idea that results. The root cause of quarrels is concerned with this.

rtsigs ma phung po'i gzugs la song // phung po yan lag rags pa las // 'phra dog sa ltar skye ba 'byung // 'grang ba bzhin du 'grang mi khyag // mi khyag bzhin du tshig la dga' // rtsod pa tha snyad tshig las 'byung // ru nga 'phra dog de las 'byung // bdag 'dzin rtsa ba sha la thug // de'i phyir dug lnga'i rtsa ba yang // mang thun sha yi rgyu la thug // sa yi dangs ma sha yin te // sa yis thams cad bskyed nas su // snang srid gdos su gyur pa bzhin // thams cad sha yi rgyus bskyed pa // nyes pa thams cad rgyus bskyed pas // nyes pa thams cad sha la thug // lhag par gti mug skyed pa'i rgyu // pha ma gnyis kyi dkar dmar yin //

The coarse elements (of meat) enter the physical body, and from the hardy physical limbs of the body envy arises coming into being like earth. Although in a state of surfeit, it cannot bear the idea of surfeit, and unable to bear it, it delights in words. Argument arises from terms and words, and malice and envy come from that. The root of selfishness is connected with flesh. Thus the root of the Five Evils is concerned with flesh as its cause. The vital form of earth is flesh. Everything is produced from earth and it is the basis of phenomenal existence. So everything is produced with flesh as its cause, and since all evils are causally produced, all evils are concerned with flesh. Especially is it the cause of the production of Ignorance (mental torpor), It is the white and red essence of parents.
gnyen 'brel kun gyi nying sha yin // mig gis mthong na skyi re 'jigs // lag tu blang na ya re nga // khong du stim pa'i lugs ci yod // sha yi nyes pa de ltar che // de las mi bza' spang ba'i rigs //

It is the ‘flesh-essence’ of all relations. If one sees this, how frightening! If one receives it, how terrible! What is this idea of absorbing it in one’s own person? So great is the evil of flesh! So let it not be eaten! It is good to avoid it.

de la so sor dbye ba yis // ltung ba'i sha la rnam pa lnga // zhe sdang 'dod chags gti mug dang // nga rgyal 'phrag dog rnam pa lnga // phung po gzugs su grub pa'i sha // zhe sdang gcan chen srin po'i sha // 'dod chags byi la dar ma'i sha //

When this matter is investigated in detail, there are five kinds of sinful flesh. This is the flesh of the five components (skandha) from which the body is made, Wrath, Desire and Ignorance (mental torpor), Pride and Envy, these are the five. With Wrath (we associate) the flesh of the flesh-eating tiger. With Lust the flesh of the lustful tom-cat.

gti mug phag rgod rngam pa'i sha // nga rgyal gyi ling nag pa'i sha // 'phrag dog sprel rgod rngam pa'i sha // de la 'bag na ltung bar byed // de bas nyes pa zur chung ba // nyes pa'i sha la rnam pa brgyad // sprel dang byi la dom dred sha // gcan gzan ri mo can gyi sha // 'dab chags ngang pa ngur ba'i sha // khyu mchog glang dang bong drel dang // nyes pa che bas [245a] spang bar bya // de bas nyes pa zur chung ba // nyams pa'i sha la bcu drug ste // gyi ling rta dang bya wang sha // ma he mdzo 'gar rtol mo'i sha // 'phar spyang wa mo bya ma byel // dbyi gsa' grum pa chu sram sha // khyim bya de pho'i sha la sogs // nyams pa che bas spang bar bya //

With Ignorance the flesh of the raging wild boar. With Pride the flesh of the black Gyi-ling horse. With Envy the flesh of the raging wild monkey. If you defile yourself with these, you commit sin. Slightly less harmful than these there are eight kinds of harmful flesh: the flesh of monkey, cat, brown bear and yellow bear, the flesh of the spotted tiger, the flesh of goose and duck, bell-wether, ox, donkey and mule. Since the evil is great, they should be avoided. Slightly less harmful than these, There are sixteen kinds of debilitating flesh: the Gyi-ling horse and the flesh of the bat, the flesh of buffalo, the dzo and her male and female crossbred offspring, the red wolf, the grey wolf, the fox and the bat, the lynx, the snow-leopard, the badger and the otter, the flesh of the domestic cock and so on, these should be avoided because they are very harmful.

de las sbyang du btub pa ni // sha rkyang gtsod rgo ri dwags sha // g.yag lug ra gsum g.yung dwags sha // sme bas ma nyams sbyang du btub // de las sme bar gyur pa ni // 'dul khrim phog pas nyes pa dang // skyes dman dag gis nyes pa dang // bar snang gza' yis nyes pa dang // zil bsgyur dag gis nyes pa bzhi // sme bar gyur pa'i nyams pa spang //

Then as for that which is capable of purification, if the flesh of the wild ass, of antelope, of wild goat, and of deer, and the flesh of the three domestic animals, yak, sheep and goat, are not harmed by defilement, purification is possible. As for defilements, these are: the harm that comes from the breaking of vows, the harm involved when a woman is the slayer, the harm involved (when the animal dies) from a nervous stroke, the harm involved when it dies of mad frenzy. One must avoid being harmed by these defilements.

spyir yang sha yi nyes pa ni // ji bzhin dug lnga cha rags pa // de bzhin nyes pa che ba ste // spang blang de yi thabs dang bstun // sbyang mi btub la gtan nas 'dzem // sbyang btub sha la gso sbyang bya // g.yung drung sems dpa'i ltung bshags dang // bde bar gshegs pa'i mtshan phyag 'tshal // ngan song sbyong ba'i snying po brjod // yan lag kha zas sde gcig go //

As for the harmfulness of flesh in general, the more gross the Five Evils, the greater the harm. Keep your practice in accordance with the method of avoiding (the evil) and accepting (the good). You must carefully avoid it when purification is not possible, and in the case of flesh where purification is possible, you must seek purification. You must make the confession of Swastika Beings and salute the Blessed Ones with invocations And recite the essential prayer which saves from evil rebirths. This is one ‘limb’ of the section on food.

rnam dag gtsug phud 'dul ba'i gshen // chang la rnam pa bzhi yin te // 'bru chang sbyar chang nying khu'i chang // shing 'bras khu ba a mri ta // 'bru chang bdud rtsi phab kyis sbyar // sbyar chang rtsi thog snying po sbyar // nying chang nying nas nying du gtig // a mri ta ni shing gi bcud //

rNam-dag gTsug-phud, O Shen who converts living beings, there are four kinds of chang, chang made from grain, chang which is blended, chang which is reduced to an essence, chang made from fruit juice, referred to as ‘ambrosia’. Chang made from grain is an elixir prepared with yeast. Blended chang is made from the essence of berries. Concentrated chang is distilled to an ever stronger concentration. Ambrosia is the essence of fruit-juice.

de yi nyams pa che chung ni // 'bru chang dag gis nyes pa che // sbyar chang dag gis nyams pa che // nying khu chang gis srog la nyen // srog la nyen pas ltung ba [245b] che // a mri ta ni bag yang tsam //

As for the degrees of harm they do: chang made from grain causes great harm; blended chang is very debilitating; distilled chang endangers one’s life, and since it is dangerous to one’s life, the sin is great; in the case of ambrosia there is little concern.

de yang u dug ra ro dang // bag med spyod 'chal 'byung bar byed // spyir yang chang gi mtshan nyid ni // lha min mtshon cha sde bzhi las // chang ni chu yi mtshon cha ste // btung bas nga rgyal che bar 'gyur // des na rang srog 'chad par byed // dug lnga nyes pa'i rtsa ba yang // rtsa ba sde gcib chang las 'byung // byams pa'i don la gnas tsam na // zhe sdang nyon mongs skye ba yang // chang gi rgyu las 'byung ba'o //

Furthermore (chang) causes drunkenness and thoughtless bad behaviour. As for the general characteristics of chang, of the four weapons of the titans chang is their liquid weapon. By drinking it self-confidence increases, and so one may cause one’s own life to be cut off. As for the harmful root-cause of the Five Evils, one part of this cause comes from chang. Even when one abides in a condition of love stirrings of the molestations (kleśa) of anger may arise with chang as their cause.

sbyin pa'i don la gnas tsam na // 'dod chags nyon mongs skye ba yang // chang gi rgyu las 'byung ba'o // ye shes don la gnas tsam na // gti mug gnyid du 'thib pa yang // chang gi rgyu las 'byung ba'o // yangs pa'i don la gnas tsam na // 'phrag dog ru nga skye ba yang // chang gi rgyu las 'byung ba'o // mnyam pa'i don la gnas tsam na // nga rgyal dregs pa skye ba yang // chang gi rgyu las 'byung ba'o // bdag gzhan mnyam par bzhag tsam na // bdag 'dzin ru nga ldang ba yang // chang gi rgyu las 'byung ba'o //

Even when one abides in a generous disposition stirrings of the molestations of desire may arise with chang as their cause. Even when one abides in a state of knowledge, a pervasion of mental torpor may arise with chang as its cause. Even when one abides in a state of broadmindedness, the stirrings of envy and malice may arise with chang as their cause. Even when one abides in a state of equality, the stirrings of pride and arrogance may arise with chang as their cause. Even when one equates oneself with others, the stirrings of self-interest and malice may arise with chang as their cause.
[f. 247a2, onwards]

chang tshong ba dang smad tshong ba // sbrang tshong ba dang rnam pa gsum // me lce 'khor lo 'bar ba yi // nang gi sgrib pa can du sbyong // gal te mtho ris gnas na yang // sdug bsngal dbul 'phongs can du bskyed // de'i phyir gdod nas spang bar bya // nyes dang nyams dang ltung ba la // bshags na sangs rgyas sman gyi lha // be du rgya 'od rgyal pos sel // de la nyes pa'i ltung bshags dang // dag cing tshangs pa'i cho ga bya // 'gro la sman gyi sbyin pa 'gyed // yan lag kha zas sde gcig go //

Purveyors of chang and prostitutes, sellers of honey, these three kinds of people, experience the inner anguish of the ‘Burning Circle of Tongues of Fire’. Even if they abide in the (three) upper Spheres (viz. gods, titans or men) they will be born in conditions of wretchedness and poverty. So one must abandon (such things) altogether. If one confesses this harm, debility and sin the Buddha Lord of Medicine, Vaidūrya the King, will wash it away. So confess this harmful sin to him and perform purificatory ceremonies, and make gifts of medicaments to living beings. This is (another) ‘limb’ of the section on food.

rnam dag gtsug phud 'dul ba'i gshen // gtsong sgog rnam pa bzhi yin te // sngon med khams mun pa zer ldan gyis // dge sdig bstan pa rtsod pa yi // dri zhim sman gyi tshal chen du // mngan sems dri ma 'thor ba la // kha dog sna bzhi'i rlang du 'phyur // de las mi zhim ljon bzhi skyes // gcig de ser po gser gyi mdog // gser gyi pad mo kha bye 'dra // sa yi rgyu bskyed dri ma ngan // gcig de sngo ljang g.yu 'od 'bar // me tog g.yu yi tshom bu 'dra // rlung gi rgyu bskyed dri ma ngan // gcig de dmar ljang zangs 'od chags // dmar ljang chun po gshib pa 'dra // [247b] me yi rgyu bskyed dri ma ngan // gcig de ne ljang ud pal mdog // rtsa ba dung po ang drag 'dra // chu yi rgyu bskyed dri ma ngan // de las so sor gyes pa yi // dug rigs sum brgya drug cu ste // rtsi dang dug gnyis mnyam par skyes // rtsi yis gsos sing dug gis bskyed // sman gyis 'joms par byed pa'o //

rNam-dag gTsug-phud, Shen who converts living beings, there are four kinds of onion and garlic. In earlier times Mun-pa zer-ldan of the Demon Realm, there being a dispute about the teachings of good and evil, scattered in the sweet-smelling grove of medicinal plants the impurities of his cursed thoughts, and they rose up as vapour of four different colours. From them four unpleasant plants came into being. One was yellow, the colour of gold. It was like an open yellow lotus flower. It was produced with earth as its cause. The smell was bad. One was bluish-green, the colour of turquoise. It was like a bunch of turquoise-coloured flowers. It was produced with wind as its cause. The smell was bad. One was reddish green, the colour of copper. It was like a well-ordered posy of reddish-green flowers. It was produced with fire as its cause. The smell was bad. One was meadow-green, the colour of an utpala lotus flower. Its root was white like conch. It was produced with water as its cause. The smell was bad. Separating from them came 360 evil kinds, and both (beneficial) juice and poison were produced. The juice cures (disease) and poison produces it. Medicine overpowers it.

spyir yang gtsong sgog nyes pa ni // sgyu lus gzugs kyi phung po ni // 'byung ba rnam pa bzhi las grub // srin bu'i grong khyer sum brgya gnas // sgog gtsong kha zas zos pa na // la la na yin la la 'chi // zhing der nad dang yams byung mtshungs // sgog gtsong nyes pa'i dri ma ni // gnas ris chen po bzhi la tshor // sangs rgyas zhing du mi gtsang dri // dbyings na bzhugs pa'i lha dang 'gal // dpag tshad lnga brgya tshun chad la // gtsang rigs mgon po'i lha mi 'khor // nus pa bcud du smin pa la // rmug dang 'thib dang bying ba dang // tshor ba rags dang chags pa skye // sred che byi la'i sde dang 'dra // sdom pa 'chal spyod dam tshig nyams // mgon skyob lha dang srung ma bye // lus la srin bu'i grong khyer dmyal // chu la grub pas ltung bar byed // me la grub pas nyes pa yin // rlung la grub pas nyams pa yin // sa la grub pas sbyang btub tsam //

As for the general harm of onion and garlic, in phenomenal bodies formed of the four elements there are 300 communities of worms. When you eat garlic and onion as your food, some of them are ill and some of them die. It is as though disease and epidemic had started in the place. The harmful impurities of garlic and onion are perceived in the four great realms. (They produce) an unclean smell in the Buddha Fields. They displease the gods who reside in space. Protecting divinities of pure lineage will not approach within a distance of 500 miles. When the potentiality (of the evil of onion-eating) develops into a concentration, sluggishness, dimness and languor, insensitivity and passionate attachment result. One is like the type of lecherous tom-cat. Vows are reduced to loose practice and sacraments are broken. Guardian divinities and protectors leave one and the communities of worms in your body all suffer. (The onion) produced from water causes sin, The one produced from fire is harmful. The one produced from wind is debilitating. The one produced from earth is just capable of purification.

ltung ba'i gtsong la 'bags pa yis // ro myags 'dam dong nang du sbyang // nyes pa'i gtsong la 'bags pa yis // mag khrag mtsho mo'i nang du sbyang // nyams pa'i gtsong la 'bags pa yis // sdug bsngal na tsha'i lus su skye // sbyang btub gtsong la ma sbyang na // lnga brgyar bse dri can du skye //

Defiled by the sinful onion, one suffers in the mud-pit of the Hell of Putrefaction. Defiled by the harmful onion, one suffers in the Lake of Pus and Blood. Defiled by the debilitating onion, wretched disease appears on one’s body. If one does not seek purification in the case of the onion which is capable of it, one is born with the stench of body-odour for 500 births.

de'i phyir shin tu spang ba'i rigs // lag tu mi blang khar mi bza' // dri ma dag [248a] kyang 'dzem par bya // spyir yang gtsong gi nyes pa ni // dug lnga nad sel sman gyi lha // be du rgya 'od rgyal pos 'byong // sman gyi mchod pa rgyun du 'bul // sman gyi sbyin pa rgyun du gtong // sman gyi cho gar brtson par bya // des na gtsong gi nyes pa 'byong //

So it is right to avoid them altogether. They should not be picked up. They should not be eaten. Even the impure smell is to be avoided. As for the harmfulness of onions in general, the Lord of Medicine, remover of the maladies of the Five Evils, Vaidūrya the King, he purifies it. Always make offerings of medicaments in worship. Always give medicaments as gifts. Exert yourself in medicinal ceremonies. By such means the harm of onions is cleansed away.

nyes skyon rtsa ba mi shes pa // lung ma bstan du zos gyur yang // gtsang rigs lha srung gnyen mi 'khor // dbang po nyams dang shes pa rmug // nyes skyon shes nas zos gyur yang // nyams dan nyes ltung 'byung bar 'gyur // yan lag kha zas sde gcig go //

Even if in ignorance of the root-cause of the harm of onions, you eat them in circumstances where nothing is asserted against them (e.g. as a layman who has not taken vows), the protecting divinities of pure lineage will not come around you. Your sense-organs will be weakened and your understanding dimmed. If you eat them in knowledge of their harmfulness, debility, harm and shin will result. This is (another) ‘limb’ of the section on food.

rnam dag gtsug phud 'dul ba'i gshen // dus ma yin gyi kha zas bzhi // srod dang tho rangs dgong mo dang // nyi ma dros dang bzhi ru ste // khrims kyi kha zas dus ma yin // srod la sha za srin pos bza' // nyi dros rgyal po gdan thog bza' // dgong mo mu steg phyin cis bza' // tho rangs -----

rNatn-dag gTsug-phud, Shen who converts living beings, there are four occasions of untimely food, twilight, dawn, evening and in the morning (9-10 a.m.). As for these times that are untimely according to rule, at twilight flesh-eating demons eat, in the morning enthroned rulers eat, in the evening false heretics eat, at dawn — [words missing].

dus kyi kha zas rnam pa gnyis // nyi ma rtse shar khrus rting la // dag pa lha yis kha zas bza' // nyi ma dgung gi dus tshod la // tshong 'dus g.yeng ba spang nas su // rgyal pos khrims kyi kha zas bza' // de min dus ma yin la gtogs // dus ma yin gyi kha zas ni // lus po shed che 'dod chags skye // tshul dang mi ldan ngo tsha bral // nad kyi rgyu rkyen ldang bar byed // lang tsho stobs shed dar rgyas bskyed // de las g.yo dang 'dzum pa dang // 'phro dang rgod dang ldem gyang 'byung //

There are two proper times for eating: after washing when the sun has risen the pure gods take their food; at noon-time kings eat their lawful food away from the distractions of the market-place. Except for these, other times are unlawful, and as for the eating of untimely food, the body becomes strong and desire increases, one loses manners and sense of shame. It produces the causes of diseases. It produces the forcefulness and lustiness of youth. From this comes playfulness and smiling, inconstancy, wildness and excitability.

dus min kha zas spang ba ni // bzhi bsdus phung po shed smad cing // bag med spyod 'chal [248b] mi 'byung phyir // dus min kha zas spang ba dang // dus kyi kha zas blang bar 'os // dus min kha zas bza' ba ni // 'dab chags ri dwags g.yung dag dang // gcan gzan rngam pa'i tshogs dang mtshungs //

As for the avoiding of untimely food, the strength of this body, compounded of the four elements, is reduced, and thoughtless loose practice does not arise, so for this reason untimely eating must be avoided, and it is proper to eat at the right times. As for eating at improper times, birds, wild animals and domestic animals, and fierce beasts of prey do the like.

dgra dang rkun bu 'jab bu dang // 'byung po ro lang tshogs rnams dang // dbye ba med par shes pa ste // khrims la 'gal bas ltung ba phog // nad du ldang bas nyes pa che // dbang po rmug pas nyams par 'gyur // de'i phyir spang ba'i rgyu ru shes // yan lag kha zas sde gcig go //

It is known that there is no difference in this from enemies, robbers and thieves, from demons and ghosts. Contravening these rules, one falls into sin. Illness is caused and the harm is great. The sense-organs are affected with languor. So know that this is something to avoid. This is (another) ‘limb’ of the section on food.

gnyis pa gon pa'i sde las su // rnam pa bzhi ru shes pa ste // rgyal po'i chas dang blon po'i chas // btsun mo'i chas dang ded dpon chas // tshon chen sde dang ri mo can // ber dang 'jol dang dpyang ras sogs // rgyal po'i cha lugs spang ba'i rgyu // dbyi spyang stag gzigs gung rgo gsa' // 'phar chen dom dred ldang 'gyu wa // chu sram sprel dang grum dkar 'phyi // spu mtshan thul pa za 'og slag // blon po'i cha lugs spang ba'i rgyu // dkar ljang dmar sngo mthon ka 'chol // sgeg dang phur dang 'jol dang sham // btsun mo'i cha lugs spang ba'i rgyu // 'phar sham gong skor mu khyud spel // ska nan brang nga phu dung can // ded dpon cha lugs spang ba'i rgyu // rgyal po'i gon pas che ba skye // blon po'i gon pas dregs pa skye // btsun mo'i gon pas chags pa skye // ded dpon gon pas rlom pa skye // lcags ri med dang lung ma bstan // g.yang gzhi lta bu srin po'i gos // spang ba'i rgyu ru bstan pa'o //

The second section, that concerning dress, may be understood as fourfold: king’s dress and minister’s dress, lady’s dress and officer’s dress. Those of a colourful kind and with patterns, cloaks and trains and hanging garments, being the dress of kings, should be avoided. Lynx, grey wolf, tiger, leopard, caracal, wild goat, snow leopard, red wolf, brown and yellow bear, — and fox, otter, monkey, white badger and marmot, such coats of fur and gowns of silk, being the dress of ministers, should be avoided. White, green, red, blue, sky-blue, gay, coquettish and fluttering, flounces and fringes, being the dress of women, should be avoided. With trimmings and collar and edgings everywhere, waisted, breasted and with fitted sleeves, such being the dress of officers, this should be avoided. Wearing king’s things, one feels important. Wearing minister’s things, one feels arrogant. Wearing women’s things, one feels lustful. Wearing officer’s things, one feels boastful. With no border and unauthorized, animal skins and the like are the dress of flesh-eating beasts. So things to be avoided have been explained.

blang ba'i gos ni 'di lta ste // srin bal kha chu la sogs [249a] te // srog bcad spu bal ma yin pa // shi shon dag las byung ba yi // dri med ras dkar gtsang ma la // ngur smrig rtsi yi kha dog sgyur //

The clothes one should wear are these, those which are not of cloth made from the silk-worm’s ‘saliva’, or from the fur and wool of slain animals, but from the pure white cloth procured from cotton, which one dyes with saffron colour.

pad lo ris drug gding ba bdun // g.yu mdangs sngon po'i mu khyud can // lcags ri 'khor yug mtha' gong med // lus kyi pags ltar gon par blang // na bza' pad lo ris drug ni // stod gos smad shams chag nan gsum // rmad gos rmad 'og tshul gos gsum // pad zhu pad lham pad gdan gsum // theg pa rim dgu'i tshogs dang sbyar // pad gdan pad lham smad shams gsum // chag nan rim bzhi rgyu yi bon // stod gos rmad gos tshul gos gsum // rmad 'og gling snam 'bras bu'i bon // pad zhu rgyu 'bras gnyis med par // bla med theg pa chen po'i tshul // thams cad kun la khyab par gnas // pad gdan gling brgyad lte ba dgu // 'khor ba'i sa la mi gnas shing // gang la chags pa med pa'i tshul // pad lham pad brtsegs gnyis sbyar te // rgyu drug 'khor ba'i lus blangs la // 'dam gyis ma gos pad ma'i tshul // smad shams sul bu nyi shu lnga // gling chung nyi shu rtsa lnga dpag // dag pa'i gling skyes dag pa'i lus // kun las rnam par 'phags pa'i tshul // chag nan rim bzhin chag gong can // tshul khrims bum pa sgeg pa dang // khrel dang ngo tsha shes pa ste // tshad med bzhi ldan byang chub rgyun // rnam dag yid 'ong sgeg pa'i tshul //

These are the six kinds of ‘lotus-leaf’ garments with a mat making seven in all. (The mat) has a blue border, the colour of turquoise, a surrounding border with no start or finish. One should accept (the six items) as wearing apparel as though they formed the skin of the body. The six kinds, of ‘lotus-leaf’ garments are these, the upper garment, the lower garment and the sandals, the special cloak, the ordinary cloak and the cope. Then there are the lotus-hat, the lotus-boots and the mat. These may be related to the ordered group of nine vehicles. The lotus-mat, the lotus-boots and the lower garment, and the sandals as fourth item (correspond with) the bon of Cause. The upper garment, the special cloak and the cope, the ordinary cloak and the patches (correspond with) the bon of Effect. The lotus-hat without differentiation of cause and effect is of the type of the supreme vehicle, remaining associated with all the others. The lotus mat with its eight sections and the centre as ninth, does not remain on terrestrial ground for it is of the type which is unattached anywhere. The lotus-boots with their dual row of lotus designs have assumed a body (as it were) in the Six Spheres of the round of existence, but resembling the lotus in type they are unsoiled by the mud. The twenty-five pleats of the lower garment, raised up as twenty-five little mounds, (represent) the supreme type of excellence of pure bodily form born in the pure isles. The sandals with the four straps in order may be known as the beautiful vase of morality (characterized by) shame and modesty, for they typify pure pleasing beauty, the flow of enlightenment with the four immeasurable virtues.

stod gos 'phrag dbyung gong bsnol med // 'dab brgyad me tog kha bye'i tshul // zhe sdang srin po'i gos mi gon // byams pa ngang ldan zhi ba'i tshul // [249b] tshul gos sul bu nyi shu lnga // lcags ri mu khyud 'khor yug can // gling bzhi gru bzhi gsal mthongs can // gtsang khrims nyi shu rtsa lnga'i tshul // g.yas pa 'og la g.yon pa steng // mdzes pa'i tshul gyis 'phrag la gzar //

The upper garment, sleeveless and without overlapping collar is of the type of the opened eight-petalled flower. Typifying loving peace, it is a garment not worn by wrathful monsters. The cope with its twenty-five pleats and its surrounding border edging, four sides, four corners and a hole in the middle, typifies the twenty-five rules of purity. Below on the right and above on the left, it hangs over the shoulders in a beautiful manner.

gtsang ma gtsug phud khrims kyi gos // smad 'og gling snam nyi shu lnga // 'tsho ba byad len mu khyud med // gtsang zhing dag par bya ba'i tshul // dge bsnyen dge tshul khrims kyi gos // rmad 'og gling snam nyi shu lnga // g.yas 'og g.yon gong gru la gzar // khrus dang mchod pa'i g.yog byar mdzes //

It is the regulation garment of the ‘top pure ones’. The lower garment with its twenty-five patches is------ and has no border. It typifies purity and cleanliness and is the lawful garment of Virtuous Adherers and novices. The ordinary cloak with its twenty-five patches, hangs over the arms below to the right and above to the left. It is beautiful as one serves in ablutions and worship.

rmad gos gling snam brgya dang brgyad // sprin dang me tog lding khang na // dgra bcom sangs rgyas brgya rtsa brgyad // 'dul ba khrims kyi bon sgo la // 'chad dang rtsod dang rtsom pa'i tshul // theg rim brgya dang rtsa brgyad la // grub pa'i 'bras bu brgya rtsa brgyad // yang dag mthar phyin rdzogs sangs rgyas // rmad du byung ba'i 'dul gos so //

The special cloak with its 108 patches and 108 buddhas in squares of cloud and flower designs, typifies (the three functions of) expounding, confounding and propounding in the manner of bon moral teachings. These are the 108 effects achieved in the 108 vehicles, and this is the wonderful monastic garment of a perfectly accomplished buddha.

pad zhu sul bu rtsa lnga la // 'dab brgyad ge sar gzhon nu'i tshul // rnam par dag pa rin chen tshul // bslab pa mthar phyin dri ma med // rgyal mtshan mthon po'i tog lta bu // dus gsum nub pa med pa ste // rnam par dag pa'i tshul 'dzin no //

The lotus-hat with its twenty-five pleats is like a young flower with eight petals (surmounted by) a pure gem. It typifies the (three) perfect and immaculate teachings (śī/a, samādhi, prajñā) and resembles the top of a tall banner of victory. It is unfailing throughout past, present and future and takes the form of purity.

de rnams kun gyi yan lag las // gzhi bskur bcud ldan pad gyes dang // hos ru gsil ba sgra snyan dang // pad cha pad khug sngon po dang // tshem khab dbal mo so leb dang // khrus bum pad gdan gtsang ma dang // lcags kyi chan gri gnyis sbyar dang // bka' rgyud rin chen gleg bam dang // sgra snyan theb tse 'khrol mo dang // pad zangs [250a] gtsang ma'i tshan snod dang // dri zhim sman gyi sdong po dang // khrims kyi gtsang rdzas sde bcu ni // rgyun du dgos pa'i yo byad do //

As ‘limbs’ (viz. implements) of all these: the begging-bowl with its contents, and open like a lotus, the jingling mendicant’s staff, the blue lotus-case for the lotus-items, the needle with point and flat end, the vase of ablution with its pure lotus-base, the metal scissors, the precious volume of traditional teachings, the sweet-sounding dish with its ringing note, the bowl of ablutions made of copper, the sweet-smelling medicinal stick, these ten lawful and pure items are things which are always required.
rnam dag gtsug phud 'dul ba'i gshen // gon pa'i sde bzhi spang bar bya // pad lo ris drug blang bar bya //
rNam-dag gTsug-phud, Shen who converts living beings, The four kinds of (wrong) apparel are to be avoided. The six ‘lotus-leaf’ garments are to be worn.
pad shun gding ba gding bar bya // pad lham pad zhu mnab par bya // gtsang rdzas sde bcu 'tshag par bya // gos kyi spang blang bstan pa'o //
The mat of lotus-fibres is to be spread. The lotus-boots and lotus-hat must be worn. The ten pure items are to be assembled. This is the section on avoiding and taking in the matter of dress.
gsum pa khri stan sde las su // rnam pa bzhi ru shes pa ste // khri stan mthon po bya ba dang // khri stan chen po bya ba dang // khri stan bzang po bya ba dang // khri stan drag po bya ba'o //
Thirdly concerning couches, These may be known as of four kinds, high couches, large couches, beautiful couches, fierce couches.

mthon po gser dngul shing gi khri // rta dang glang po ma he dang // bong drel la sogs rkang 'gros te // mthon po yin pas spang bar bya // de la so sor dbye ba na // gser dngul shing khri chen po'i khri // gnas pa'i yul la chags pa skye // rta dang glang po ma he'i khri // khengs sems dregs dang nga rgyal skye // mdzo dang bong drel dman pa'i khri // rabs chad ma ning u dug sgra // shin tu dman pas nyams pa che //

High couches are of gold, silver or wood. They include riding animals, horses, elephants and buffaloes, donkeys, mules and so on. Because they are high, they must be avoided. If we distinguish the details, great couches of gold and silver and wood produce feelings of attachment to the place of your stay. Horses, elephants and buffaloes, used as seats, produce feelings of boastfulness, arrogance and pride. Dzo, donkeys and mules are demeaning seats. Animals that are impotent or neuter or make unpleasant sounds are very demeaning and this is very harmful.
chen po skyes dman za ma mo // nyams len yid 'phrog snang ba 'khrul // lha mo klu mo mi mo dang // bdud mo srin mo dman mo'i rigs // rnam pa drug tu phyed pa'o //

As for large couches, women and feminine creatures rob your learning and your thoughts and confuse all appearances. Goddesses, mermaids, women, demonesses, ogresses and prostitutes, they are distinguished as six kinds.

lha mo yid 'phrog snang ba 'khrul // klu mo mdzes ldan le lo g.yeng // mi mo 'gro ba'i bag chags g.yo // bdud mo ge shan srog la rgol // srin mo za byed bla yid rku // dman mo grong rgyu log par slu // thar lam 'gegs pa'i geg shing byed //

Goddesses steal your thoughts and confuse appearances. Mermaids are beautiful and distract you with indolence. Women arouse latent impulses. Demonesses are murderous and assail your life. Ogresses are (flesh-)eaters and steal away your spirit and your thought. Prostitutes go around the village and deceive you. They act as blocks obstructing the way of salvation.

spyir yang nyes [250b] pa'i mtshan nyid ni // rin chen sa 'og sbas pa dang // shel sgong 'dam du bskyur ba dang // rtsi thog ba mos bcom pa dang // me long g.ya' yis bsgribs pa dang // nyi ma sprin gyis g.yogs pa dang // zla ba gza' yis zin pa dang //

In general these are the signs of harm: a jewel hidden under the ground, a crystal ball thrown in the mud, juicy fruit destroyed by hoar-frost, a mirror disfigured by rust, the sun obscured by clouds, the moon seized by eclipse,

dar dkar dri mas bsgos pa dang // sgron me 'od mdangs nyams pa dang // dpag bsam sdong po rul ba dang // me tog sad kyis khyer ba dang // rnga gshang sgra skad chag pa dang // nyams dang nyes dang ltung ba che //

white silk soiled by a stain, a lamp rendered feeble by daylight, a tree of paradise turned rotten, a flower destroyed by the frost, a drum or a bell with a cracked sound. They are debilitating, harmful and sinful.

bdud mo gdan du bting ba na // ro myags 'dam dong nag po ru // gtan tu thar med sdug bsngal sbyang // srin mo gdan du bting ba na // me lce 'khor lo 'bar ba ru // gdar tshan dmar po'i sbub la sbyang // dman mo gdan du bting ba na // chu gling mun pa'i rgya mtsho ru // klu srin pho mo'i lus blang zhing // 'dod pa tshim med nyon mongs skye // mi mo gdan du bting ba na // mngal gyi srin bu'i grong khyer na // sdug bsngal thar med btson ra sbyang // klu mo gdan du bting ba na // gling bar mun pa'i glin khrod na // dbang bo ma tshangs gya nyes sbyang // lha mo gdan du bting ba na // mtha' 'khob ma dag grong khyer du // sdug bsngal na tsha'i lus su sbyang // spyi ru nyes pa de ltar che // sgos su 'dul ba 'dzin pa yi // bslab gsum 'jug spyod gang zag rnams // lus kyis spyad na ltung ba che // ngag gis spyad na nyes pa che // yid kyis bsam na nyams pa che // lus ngag yid gsum log pa na // shin tu nyams pa chen po ste // rdza chag 'phro bzhin bskang bar dka' // de phyir chen po'i khri stan spang //

If you have a demoness as your couch, you will experience suffering with no hope of salvation in the black mud pit of the Hell of Putrefaction. If you have an ogress as your couch, you will experience the recess of red hot metal in the Hell of the Burning Circle of Tongues of Fire. If you have a prostitute as your couch, (in your next birth) you will have the body of a male or female sea-monster in the ocean of the dark isles, and you will feel the molestations of unsated desire. If you have a woman as your couch, you will experience the prison of suffering with no hope of salvation in the community of worms of the womb. If you have a mermaid as your couch, you will experience the evil of deformity, (born) with limbs incomplete in the dark group of isles between the (great) continents. If you have a goddess as your couch, you will experience a sick body of suffering in the impure barbarian country. In general the harm is as great as this. In particular those people who have started and are practising the threefold teaching which comprises monastic discipline, are greatly in sin, if they so act with their body, do very great harm, if they so act with their speech, are much debilitated, if they so think with their mind. If body, speech and mind are at fault, one is very much debilitated. However long one continues, it is hard to fill a broken pot. Therefore large couches must be avoided.
bzang [251a] po dar dang zab kyi gdan // srin dang za 'og 'bol gdan de // ri mo can dang mu khyud can // nyi zla ris dang nor bu ris //
Beautiful ones are of fine or heavy silk, mattresses of fine cloth and brocade, finely patterned and bordered, with designs of sun and moon and designs of gems,

g.yung drung 'khor lo pad ma ris // me tog tshom bu pa tra ris // dpag bsam shing lo gzha' sprin ris // dkar ljang dmar sngo mthing nag ris // kha dog sna lnga gzha' mtshon ris // 'jam dang bde dang 'bol ba ste // lus po bag yangs chags pa skye // btsun mo'i gdan yin spang bar bya //

designs of swastikas, wheels and lotuses, flowers in clusters and criss-cross designs, leaves of the tree of paradise, designs of rainbow and clouds, white, green, red, blue, sky-blue and black in design, colours of all five kinds, designs of rainbow hues, soft, comfortable and springy, the body is at ease and lust is aroused. Such are the couches of women and must be avoided.
drag po gcan gzan ris bkra ste // gtum chen dom dang rngam chen dred // mi rgod rngam pa'i pags pa gsum // gdan du bting na ltung ba phog //
Fierce ones are adorned with wild animals, the skins of the fierce brown bear, the raging yellow bear or the terrible gorilla. If these are laid down as mats, sin is committed.
sha zhan stag dang thig le gzigs // dpa' rtsal sing dang ngar can gsa' // wal wol gung dang 'phar spyang dbyi // gdan du bting na nyes par 'gyur //

The flesh-eating tiger and the spotted leopard, the bold skilful lion and the powerful snow-leopard, the restive caracal, the red wolf, the grey wolf and the lynx, If these are laid down as mats, it is harmful.

rbad dang wa sbrel khyi dang grum // sme ba'i gdan yin nyams par 'gyur // gdan khri nyams na khri 'phang gdeg // khri 'phang dgu pa'i mchod rten bzhengs // rin chen bkad sa thang la nyal // gding ba g.yu mdangs gdan du gding // de min khri gdan spang bar bya //

The excitable fox, the monkey, the dog and the badger, These are mats that defile, and this is debilitating. If you violate (the rules) in the matter of your couch, you must erect nine steps, you must build a stupa with (a base of) nine steps. Sleep on the ground in a precious (viz. religious) shelter. You should put down as a mat a turquoise-coloured cloth. Otherwise you should do without couch and mat.

rnam dag gtsug phud 'dul ba'i gshen // mthon po'i khri stan nyes par 'gyur // chen po'i khri stan ltung bar 'gyur // bzang po'i khri stan chags par 'gyur // drag po'i khri stan nyams par 'gyur // khri stan dag gi dbye ba'o //

O rNam-dag gTsug-phud, Shen who converts living beings! High couches are harmful. Large couches are sinful. Beautiful couches are lustful. Fierce couches are debilitating. Such are the differences in the matter of couches.
bzhi pa grogs kyi sde las su // chags pa'i grogs dang 'gal ba'i grogs // nyes pa'i grogs dang nyams pa'i grogs // rnam pa bzhi ru shes par bya //
Fourthly the section on friends. There are clinging friends and erring friends, harmful friends and debilitating friends. Thus they are of four kinds.

gnyen dang nye du 'brel ba rnams // chags pa'i grogs yin rgyang [251b] thag bsring // bsnyo 'bog rla rdol gdon gyis brlam // 'gal ba'i grogs yin bar mtshams gcad // skyes dman bud med bslu brid can // nyes pa'i grogs yin rgyang thag bsring //

Relatives and those who are closely connected are clinging friends and must be kept at a distance. Crazy, excitable people, those possessed of demons make erring friends from whom one must cut oneself off. Women who lead one into temptation are harmful friends who must be kept at a distance.
dam tshig nyams dang sme mnol can // nyams pa'i grogs yin thabs kyis spang //
Those who have broken their vows and are defiled are debilitating friends and must be methodically avoided.

spyir yang grogs kyi nyes pa ni // thar lam mi thob gag shing byed // dge ba'i las la bar chod gtong // phyin ci log gi bslu khar 'gro // mi mthun rkyen g.yo sar sna 'khrid // de bas thabs kyis spang bar bya //

In general then this evil of (bad) friends acts as a block so that you miss the way of salvation. They put obstructions in the way of virtuous acts. You go the ways of false deceit and they lead you into the crooked way of untoward events. So they must be methodically avoided.

de las bzlog ste mthun pa'i grogs // tshangs par spyod dang mthun par ldan // dad dang brtse sems mos gus che // blo sems mi 'gyur 'gyur med sems // dad ldan zung thub dam tshig can // rnam dag dka' thub srung khrims ldan // zhi tshul ngang ring khong 'khyul can // blang ba'i grogs su shes pa'o //

The opposite of these are those suitable friends, who are pure in conduct and fitting persons, faithful, loving and respectful, constant and unchanging in mind, faithful, understanding and true to their vows, keeping to pure austere practices and obeying the rules, gentle, forbearing and patient, one knows these as the friends one should have.

rnam dag gtsug phud 'dul ba'i gshen // chags pa'i grogs kyis ltung bar byed // 'gal ba'i grogs kyis nyes par byed // nyams pa'i grogs kyis ltung bar byed // nyes pa'i grogs kyis sme bar byed // grogs kyi yan lag bstan pa'o //

rNam-dag gTsug-phud, Shen who converts living beings, clinging friends cause sin, erring friends cause harm, debilitating friends cause sin, harmful friends defile. The ‘limb’ of friends has now been taught.

de ltar yan lag sde bzhi las // kha zas sde dang gon pa'i sde // khri stan sde dang grogs kyi sde // thabs la brten te bsrung ba'i rgyu // yan lag kha zas de bzhi la // shin tu srog la nyes pas su // nad la sman du 'gro ba dang // theg pa gong du spar bas su // de min gzhan la dgag par shes // thabs la brten te bsrung ba'o //

So in the matter of these four ‘limbs', the section on food and the section on dress, the section on couches and the section on friends, these are matters to observe and hold to methodically. As for the four items in the section on food, except when there is danger to your life and they serve as medicine for illness, and unless you transfer to a higher vehicle, know that these items are otherwise forbidden. These are matters to observe and to hold to methodically.
rang bzhin gyis ni spyod tshul la // [252a] sgeg mos me long phyi ba bzhin // yang yang phyi zhing yang yang lta // ngang pa'i rgyal rigs khrus byed bzhin // skad gcig mi yeng rtse gcig srung //

As for the manner of your own practice, Be like the beautiful girl who wipes the mirror, who wipes it continually and looks in it continually. Be like the royal goose who when he is washing does not wander for one moment but remains intent.
